Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the mother should purchase it
Situation2: They spot a child struggling in the deep end where swimming is restricted.
Story:
I stood at the edge of the pool, whistle in hand, scanning the water for any sign of trouble. My mind, though, kept drifting to my son’s hopeful eyes this morning, his voice echoing, “You promised, Mom. You said I’d get a Nintendo if I did well in school.” I wanted so badly to keep that promise, but the bills piling up at home made every dollar feel precious. As a mother, I was supposed to provide, to make him happy, to keep our little world stable.

Suddenly, a splash caught my attention. A child, not my own, was flailing in the deep end—an area strictly off-limits. My training kicked in: enforce the rules, keep everyone safe, act fast. But my thoughts tangled. If I left my post for even a moment, I risked my job, the paycheck that kept our lights on and maybe, just maybe, could buy that Nintendo. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations pressing in from both sides, feeling the impossible pull between being the mother my son needed and the lifeguard everyone else depended on.
